title: 110_s1003
content:
The "Access to Emergency Medical Services Act of 2007" establishes a Bipartisan Commission on Access to Emergency Medical Services, additional payments for certain physicians' services, and a Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services Working Group to improve emergency care efficiency. The United States Bipartisan Commission on Access to Emergency Medical Services is established to improve emergency care efficiency. The Commission is tasked with identifying factors affecting the delivery of screening and stabilization services in hospitals with emergency departments under EMTALA. It must also make recommendations to Congress on federal programs and policies to ensure the availability of these services and coordinate disaster response programs. The Commission will examine factors related to emergency departments of hospitals, including crowded conditions, patient boarding, barriers to access for emergency medical treatment, and legal and financial liability of healthcare professionals. The Commission will consider changes in Federal law, funding sources, and alternative approaches to protect healthcare professionals and providers from legal and financial liability regarding emergency medical services under EMTALA. The text discusses protecting healthcare providers from liability under EMTALA and coordinating emergency medical services during disasters. Definitions for "hospital" and "EMTALA" are provided. SEC. 103. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 24 members appointed within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. The President, Speaker of the House, and Senate majority leader each appoint 8 members. The Commission established by the Act consists of 24 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate majority leader. Each appoints 8 members, including representatives from emergency medical professionals, government officials, health care advocates, and hospital systems. The Commission elects a chairperson and 4 vice chairpersons from its members. The Commission members are appointed for life, with vacancies filled for the remainder of the term. They serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses while performing their duties. The Commission members are appointed for life and serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses while performing their duties. A quorum consists of 9 members, with 6 or more able to conduct a hearing. Meetings are called by the chairperson or a majority of members. SEC. 104. STAFF AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission may appoint staff and consultants as necessary without following certain provisions of the United States Code. Consultants can be hired at specific rates, and federal employees can be detailed upon request. Federal agency heads can detail personnel to assist the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status and privileges. SEC. 105. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. The Comptroller General can conduct studies upon request, and the Congressional Budget Office must provide cost estimates when requested by the Commission. The Commission can request technical assistance from Federal agencies and use the United States mails for communication. It may also obtain information directly for its duties. The Commission can obtain necessary information from Federal agencies, receive administrative support services from the General Services Administrator, accept donations, and be considered a committee of Congress for printing purposes. The Commission will submit a report to Congress and the Secretary of Health and Human Services within 18 months of the Act's enactment, with recommendations to improve emergency medical services. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report, and necessary funds are authorized for this purpose. TITLE II--ADDITIONAL PAYMENTS FOR CERTAIN PHYSICIANS' SERVICES

SEC. 201. ADDITIONAL PAYMENTS FOR CERTAIN PHYSICIANS' SERVICES. Section 1833 of the Social Security Act is amended to include an additional payment of 10 percent for physicians' services provided in the emergency department of a hospital to individuals covered under the insurance program. This payment is made from the Federal Supplementary Trust Fund. The amendment made by subsection (a) will apply to services provided on or after January 1, 2008. TITLE III--CENTERS FOR MEDICARE & MEDICAID SERVICES WORKING GROUP TO IMPROVE EMERGENCY CARE EFFICIENCY. This section establishes a working group within the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to enhance the efficiency of emergency care. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will convene a CMS working group to develop boarding and diversion standards for hospitals and guidelines for implementation and enforcement. The CMS working group will identify barriers to timely patient admissions and best practices to improve patient flow in hospitals. A report must be submitted to Congress and the Secretary of Health and Human Services within 2 years of the enactment of this Act. The CMS Working Group will submit a detailed report to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, including standards, guidelines, barriers, best practices, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions. The group may request information from hospitals as needed. The group will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will disclose information about hospitals that fail to report requested information to the CMS working group. The term "hospital" includes hospitals and critical access hospitals as defined in the Social Security Act.
